output.conclusion: By completing this course, you have gained advanced knowledge in database design principles, normalization techniques, transaction management, and query optimization. You are now equipped to design and implement robust, scalable, and efficient database systems for complex applications.
output.introduction: Welcome to Advanced Database Design! This course delves into the intricacies of designing and implementing efficient and scalable database systems. We will explore advanced normalization techniques, transaction management, query optimization, and NoSQL database concepts. This course is designed for experienced database professionals and developers seeking to enhance their database design skills.

chapters.description: Review of Normal Forms (1NF, 2NF, 3NF, BCNF). Introduction to 4NF and 5NF. Practical examples of denormalization and its impact on performance.
Understanding temporal data. Implementing valid-time and transaction-time databases. Querying temporal data using SQL extensions.
Introduction to spatial data types and indexing. Implementing spatial queries and analysis. Integrating spatial data with relational databases.
Deep dive into transaction isolation levels (Read Uncommitted, Read Committed, Repeatable Read, Serializable). Understanding concurrency control mechanisms.
Exploring different locking mechanisms (shared locks, exclusive locks, optimistic locking, pessimistic locking). Deadlock detection and resolution.
Ensuring atomicity, consistency, isolation, and durability (ACID) in database transactions. Implementing concurrency control strategies for high-performance systems.
Understanding query execution plans. Indexing strategies for query optimization. Using query hints and performance tuning tools.
Exploring advanced indexing techniques (bitmap indexes, function-based indexes, clustered indexes). Index maintenance and optimization.
Implementing database partitioning and sharding for scalability. Horizontal and vertical partitioning strategies. Data distribution and management.
Introduction to NoSQL databases (key-value stores, document databases, column-family stores, graph databases). CAP theorem and data consistency models.
Designing data models for document databases (MongoDB, Couchbase). Indexing and querying document data. Data aggregation and analysis.
Introduction to graph databases (Neo4j). Modeling relationships and graph structures. Implementing graph queries and algorithms.
